reviewText: Budget brand VHS mfr. GOODTIMES HOME VIDEO tapes were recorded at LP speed and didn't include a Hi-Fi audio track, just a linear one. This means a less-sharp picture than from standard SP videos, and mono-only sound of middling quality. Their BEST OF JOHN WAYNE five movie set is a space waster: a block of five slow speed tapes with an hour movie on each. In LP mode, GOODTIMES could have fit four movies on a single tape. . As for these pre-Stagecoach Duke Wayne westerns: he's young, unpolished and working on a shoestring with other 'B' unit actors and technicians. Duke's fans and perhaps western aficionados will want to see these slight movies. I've owned 20 old Wayne programmers for almost a decade and still haven't seen half of them, so that's where I stand! I also have a six-hour "all-night westerns" tape with other actors. It works pretty well for 25 years old. Related DVD item: BCI's 6-disc set, LEGENDS OF HOLLYWOOD - JOHN WAYNE has all these, plus 14 more Wayne westerns and a drama, also ONE-EYED JACKS (1961) and THE SUNDOWNERS (1950). Additionally, there's 32 of Duke's movie trailers! Parenthetical numbers preceding titles are 1 to 10 IMDb viewer poll ratings. (5.4) Riders of Destiny (1933) - John Wayne/Cecilia Parker/Forrest Taylor/'Gabby' Hayes/Al St. John/Heinie Conklin/Yakima Canutt (5.7) Hell Town ("Born to the West") (1937) - JW/Marsha Hunt/Johnny Mack Brown/Monte Blue/Lucien Littlefield (5.2) Sagebrush Trail (1933) - JW/Nancy Shubert/Lane Chandler/Yakima Canutt/Hal Taliaferro/Bob Burns (5.0) The Dawn Rider (1935) - JW/Marion Burns/Dennis Moore/Yakima Canutt (4.9) The Man From Utah (1934) - JW/Polly Ann Young/'Gabby' Hayes/George Cleveland
